newsitem.title: USA: UPS sued for breach of contract, negligence.
newsitem.headline: UPS sued for breach of contract, negligence.

text.p: An Oklahoma lawyer has filed a federal lawsuit against United Parcel Service on behalf of a number of small and medium-sized companies charging the shipper with breach of contract and negligence, he said on Saturday.
"Our cause of action is against UPS for negligence on the part of the management of UPS as well as breach of express and implied contracts," attorney Bob Joyner said.
A UPS spokeswoman said the company does not comment on pending litigation.
Joyner said the suit's initial request is for damages of $75,000, the minimum required in federal court, but that the final number is likely to be higher.

The suit, which seeks class action status and was filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Oklahoma City, claims that UPS encouraged customers to continue shipping products even though it knew a strike was imminent, Joyner said.
UPS is currently locked in negotiations with the Teamsters union in an effort to reach a settlement that would end a 13-day-old strike by 185,000 UPS workers.
The strike has paralyzed the nation's largest package delivery firm and caused many UPS customers to scramble to find other ways of shipping their products.
Many small businesses are feeling the pinch of being unable to deliver their goods.
UPS competitors such as the U.S. Postal Service, Federal Express Corp. and Airborne Express have rushed to fill the void.

Joyner said the named plaintiff in the suit is Microm Computer Ltd., a Normal, Okla. computer maker, but the final number of plaintiffs could reach the hundreds. He said he was unaware of any other similar suits filed against UPS.
